title: 110_hr5954
content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with service in the armed forces and exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Project 112. Presumption of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112 is added to title 38, United States Code. This includes diseases incurred or aggravated by service, even without evidence during that period. The diseases must be diagnosed to qualify. The Secretary can presume service connection for diagnosed diseases related to increased exposure to toxic agents during military service, including chemical or biological warfare projects. Exposure to toxic agents during military service, including chemical or biological warfare projects under Project 112, can lead to service-connected diseases in veterans. Veterans who served on active duty and were exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 are presumed to have been exposed to toxic agents associated with diseases unless conclusive evidence proves otherwise. Veterans exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 are presumed to have been exposed to toxic agents associated with diseases unless conclusive evidence proves otherwise. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for the disease covered by the determination. The Secretary will provide regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases related to exposure to toxic agents during Project 112 testing. This determination is based on evidence of a positive association between the exposure and the disease. The Secretary will establish regulations for presuming service connection for diseases linked to exposure to toxic agents during Project 112 testing, considering sound medical and scientific information. The Secretary will consider all medical and scientific information when evaluating reports for determining associations between diseases and exposure to toxic agents. Positive associations will be based on credible evidence outweighing evidence against the association. For the purposes of this subsection, exposure to a toxic agent is considered positive if credible evidence supports the association. If the presumption of service connection for a disease is removed, veterans and survivors previously awarded compensation will continue to receive benefits. The presumption of service connection for a disease before the effective date of its removal entitles veterans and survivors to continue receiving compensation and benefits. Project 112 refers to the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense or other federal agencies. Project 112, the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense and other federal agencies from 1963 to 1973, is defined in this section. The table of sections in the chapter is amended to include this definition. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with service in support of chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Regulations, personnel records, and report concerning Project 112. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must transmit personnel records to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within 30 days for those exposed. A report is required within 1 year of enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide records of personnel exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. A report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year, documenting costs, benefits, and challenges associated with the project. Project 112, a chemical and biological weapons program, conducted by the Department of Defense or other federal agencies, requires a full accounting of all information known about participants. The Department of Veterans Affairs must address concerns held by veterans and veterans service organizations regarding Project 112. Project 112, a chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense and other federal agencies from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD.
